text:
Fantastic recipe! This is a good one to do when you're busy. Chop the veggies the night before, and defrost the meat in the fridge. Finish cutting the meat in the morning and toss it all in. Dinner is ready when you get home!

I didn't have "Cajun seasoning" but I had Zataran's Creole Seasoning. It worked for us. The next time I do this, I think I will saute the veggies (I also added a carrot) before putting it in the slow cooker to add a more caramelized flavor. I will definitely make it againl

Display Name:
mele jean

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/651650.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I'm from the south and my boyfriend is New Orleans bred so I can tell you, this is not authentic New Orleans Jambalaya...however, whatever you want to call it, it's AWESOME! We both love it and will definitely be making it again. I used two chicken breasts, which wasn't enough..next time I will probably use 4. I used 1/2 the amount of cayenne and there was plenty of heat. I did use spicy fire roasted diced tomatoes and "Slap Yo Mama" seasoning for the cajun seasoning, so I'm sure that contributed to the heat. Also added about 1 1/2 teaspoons of chopped garlic. It's fine without the shrimp, but who turns down shrimp! Either way will be very satisfying. I boiled about 3 cups of brown rice separately and dumped it in the last 20 minutes. First night it was a little soupy but we were very pleased with the flavor. 2nd night it thickened up closer to jambalaya status, but not what we down south consider jambalaya. Regardless, it's a great cajun dish that is definitely going to become a regular with us. Thanks for sharing.

I made this yesterday, and this was delicious...had to make a few substitutions as I was out of chicken broth, so used cream of chicken soup and rinsed the can out with White Zinfandel.  My wife doesn't normally like my Cajun cooking, but she loved this one...but had to give her a plate before I put the shrimp in.  We're going to cut up and ziploc these ingredients, then slow cook all day when we go horse camping...after a long ride, this will be just the treat, and use the bags of microwave rice to keep it all simple.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Although I tweaked the recipe (as I always do), the base recipe for this jambalaya was excellent. Up until then, we had only had Zatarains brand jambalaya from a box (I'm sorry to say) and had not had the pleasure of tasting something truly authenticly cajun - until now. Since then, we've actually eaten jambalaya at a real cajun restaurant, and I must say that this jambalaya tastes as good or better. We tweaked the recipe by removing the cayenne and doubling up on the creole seasoning, substituting basil for oregano, and substituting the andouille sausage for regular old smoked sausage (only because we like it better). Otherwise we stayed true to the recipe and we love it! It has become a staple dish at our house.
Review:

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe is great!  I followed the recipe exactly and it turned out perfectly.  It is a bit soupy but I used some of the excess liquid to make my rice (I used a mix of the jambalaya liquid & chicken stock to make a flavorful rice).  I served the Jambalaya over the rice and then stored the leftover Jambalaya & rice together in a container.  The rice absorbs some of the excess liquid so when you reheat it, it tastes great & the rice is moist.  My husband swears it was better the second day.  I will definetly make this again.  I think the only thing I will add is some garlic.  The rest is perfection!

text:
First time I have ever made Jambalaya and I do have to say it turned out GREAT! I just made it a little different because I didn't have the time to put in it in a slower cooker so I made on the stove top. Browned all meat(used whatever sauage I had)first sepreatly then removed it, cooked onion till yellow then added everything in and let it cook till most of liquids were gone, cooked rice and that's it! Ohh I did add a hot green pepper not sure what kind but I seeded it and deveined it and chopped it, and a teaspoon of minced garlic, turned out great!

I made this on the stove top instead of crock pot and it was delicious.  I used crushed tomatoes instead of diced by mistake, but worked out great.  I add a box of Zataran's Jambalaya rice into it at the end which adds extra spice and it is wonderful.  Made this for friends who absolutely loved it as well.  Will definately make again. text:
This was a really good recipe!  That being said, I'll tell you that I am being a total hypocrite because I can't stand people who don't follow a recipe and then rate it but this time I was one of those people...I didn't have chicken breasts so I used thighs and I didn't  have dried parsley.  Toward the end of cooking I thought it lacked a little sale so I added a teaspoon, which made a huge difference.  I agree with others, too...this recipe is rather wet so I would try one of three things...cooking the rice in the crock pot, reducing the liquids by about 1/3 or cooking on high with the lid off for the last half hour to hour.  Overall really good though.

I didn't have time to do this in the slow cooker so I dry fried the chicken with the herbs/spices then added the vegetables (plus 4 chopped cloves garlic), tomatoes, chicken stock and some paella rice. Brought it up to the boil and cooked stirring constantly for 40 minutes.  It was delicious. The whole family raved about it.  We get a lot of paella in Spain but it was nice to have something with a bit more bite.  Thanks for posting Colleen.

country:
None
text:
This is a good base recipe, just needs a little tweaking. I added 2 tablespoons of tomato paste and 5 dashes of worchester sauce to help deepen the flavor a bit. The jambalaya was very thin and soupy, so I added okra and made a slurry with 2 tablespoons of flour and 5 tablespoons of the hot liquid from the recipe to thicken it up. Also, be aware that the chicken can become rubbery if cooked to long, so cut the chunks larger and that helps.

I give this 5 stars; however, I will agree with other reviews and say that it is very soupy.  I followed the recipe to the letter.  I cooked rice separate from the Jambalaya, and in the end the Jambalaya came out pretty soupy.  Next time I make this, I'll use the extra liquids from the Jambalaya to cook the rice. This is a good starter recipe but needs work on the seasonings.  I didn't add the cayenne pepper until after so I could adjust the heat for my family.  It's pretty bland, cayenne pepper adds heat, not flavor ... added extra cajun seasoning (I used Emerils) and then added some Old Bay seasoning as well.  I would give it 4 stars with those adjustments.  It still doesn't have that authentic jambalaya taste you get at cajun restaurants.

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was pretty good.  My first jambalaya recipe, so I didn't have any basis for comparison.  Normally, I wouldn't write a review if I made changes, but I don't think the changes I made affected the outcome of the recipe--I just thought I would note it for future reference...My husband doesn't like onions and peppers, so I pureed all the veggies except the tomatoes, and dumped all the ingredients in the slow cooker to sit in the fridge overnight.  Made it very easy the next morning to just plug in and go.  The flavor was super.  The texture wasn't so great.  Kinda grainy.  I would have preferred it chunky, but the end result was really good.  I served it over brown rice.

text:
I really wanted to like this, but in the end I just thought it was ok.  I will try it today for leftovers to see if the flavors have jelled a little bit.  I only cooked it for 4 hours in the crock pot because my chicken needed to thaw.  My veggies were still crisp.  I think this is one of those dishes you don't want to hurry.  The other thing about this recipe is that it is VERY spicy.  I have a spicy palette and add Tabasco to almost everything.  I had the bottle of Tabasco on the table and almost added it before I tasted it.  I decided I better taste it first if I was going to rate it and boy I'm glad I did.  This was spicy.  I thought with the amount of meat and liquid and rice the spice would be absorbed.  Spicy was all I could taste- no other spice.  I would cut the spice in half- most people would not be able to tolerate that amount of spiciness.  I did not find any thing off with the amount of liquid in the dish.  Thanks for sharing.  I'm glad I finally tried this one.

text:
EASY recipe! Prep time was on the mark. Only 3 minor changes. I used cleaned shrimp from the fish counter at supermarket instead of frozen. Also used hot Italian sausage because could not find the Cajun type.  Omitted the cayenne pepper due not knowing if Cajun sausage was hot spicy or just different spices than mild Italian sausage. I thought if it was not spicy enough when time to add shrimp then I would add the cayenne pepper. I like my spicy dishes medium to hot. With the hot sausage it was hot enough for me. My family does not like hot but they loved this recipe. My brother-in-law, who does not eat leftovers, asked me to save the rest for his lunch the next day.  I thought it had the right amount of sauce. I served it with French bread to soak up the sauce. Yum! Yum! When I made it again I will add the rice or rice noodles to the cooker instead of making it separately.  Definitely will add okra next time. Did not think about it until the dish had been on the cooker for a couple of hours and did not want to go to store to get the okra.

This was a great recipe. country:
None
text:
This was very easy and very good.  I omitted the green pepper, celery and cayenne pepper because I did not have them on hand and used tomatoes with chiles (drained), celery seed, and a few shakes of red hot for flavor.  Also used some smoked sausage for the andouille, used raw shrimp, and added rice and another cup or so of water to the pot a couple of hours before serving.  I ended up having it in the crock longer than expected, so everything melded together more than I would have liked, but the outcome was delicious.  Served both with and without a little sour cream to ease the heat since I used a spicy sausage and extra seasoning.  I'll make it again, but I think the listed cook time could easily be cut in half, at least.

city:

country:
None
text:
I made this today and it was great! The only subbing I did was I added about 1/4-1/2 cup more fat free chicken broth(accidentally!), used 2 cans of tomatoes to make the total amt and one was italian seasoned(figure I would be adding oregona anyways so no big deal), left out the red pepper, and since I couldn't find andouille sausage I used Tony Chachere's chicken with green onion and jalapeno sausage. This dish did not come out spicy though it got hotter the more I ate. If my re-heats are the same next time I may add a bit more. I was afraid the sausage would be too hot but it wasn't. I used the high setting for 4 hours then added precooked shrimp I had thawed in the fridge then put under hot water to finish thawing. I let it cook on high probably another 20 min while i fixed some 10 min brown rice. I got about 9 generous 1 cup servings and it was weight watchers friendly. The sausage and shrimp I used were both less than a pound (14 oz for the sausage and about 12-13 oz for the shrimp)I ate with 1/2 cup brown rice in a bowl since the extra broth wasn't needed!  good recipe and I will make this again. thanks for sharing!

text:
I made this for superbowl and I was very impressed!  Everyone loved it.  This is  soupy, but we prefered that and wanted a recipe that had some broth to it.  I cooked rice seperatly and put the jambalaya over it.  I followed the recipe exactly as is and i'm glad i did.   The seasonings are perfect.  It is about a "medium" for spicy.   It was too spicy for my kids, but perfect for the adults :)  The taste is wonderful and I thought it packed a lot of flavor.   Oh, I highly recommend buying deveind, peeled, RAW shrimp instead of cooked...the raw shrimp is a much better texture ...doesn't seem as "rubbery" as the pre-cooked can seem.   I put the shrimp in about 1 hour before it was done and it was cooked perfect.   I will make this recipe often

text:
This is a good base recipe as is or modified based on preferences or available ingredients.  I used 2 cups of cooked chicken (left overs from a roasted chicken).  I used 2 (14 oz) cans of diced tomatoes (one with chiles) as someone else had mentioned and then only added a dash of cayenne.  I added 2x the chicken broth. I added 1.5 cups of rice when I added the shrimp (uncooked instead of cooked) and turned heat to high.

country:

text:
We had a family baby shower this weekend and were trying to decide what to feed everyone after church.  There were going to be 30 adults to feed.  My son said he didn't want it to be a hassle so he bought a $100 worth of chopped beef at the famous TX BBQ place we have here.  Well, during the suggesting of what to make I said "how about Jambalaya?"  Well the mom to be wasn't really happy on that idea, but I thought I would make a batch for her to taste.  It ended up that she didn't get a chance.  It sat in my refridgerator for a couple of days.  I decided to make some rice and add two pounds of shrimp and if they eat it, they eat it.  OMG, they came inside to fix their plates and they went straight to the Jambalaya.  I had throw away bowls to serve it in and they went on and on and on about how good it was.  My greatest compliment came from my housekeeper who was born and raised in New Orleans.  She said it was excellent.    This is important for people just taking a taste.  Everyone commented on this.  When you take the first couple of bites you think it's not seasoned well.  Then on that third bite it bites you back and don't know why but your tongue wakes up and your mind and tummy say OMG, this here is some mighty fine vittles.  Then you can't get enough.   I am so glad that it made enough for everyone to try it.  Everyone did too because so much talk was going on about it and the delay to the taste buds.  Thanks Colleen.  Got anymore great recipes?  I'm going look!!

text:
Awesome recipe.  I read the reviews and tried to cut the juices down a bit, but it was a still little too juicy.  I cut the broth down to between 2/3 and 3/4 cups, and next time I'll cut that down to 1/2 cup and add 1/2 teaspoon chicken bouillon, and drain one can of the tomatoes (I used 2 14 ounce cans).  I also couldn't find the andouille, subbed smoked kielbasa and added a little more cajun and cayenne.  Got rave reviews from everyone!

This was a good recipe but watch the spices 1 tps of my homade cajun and a 1/4 tsp.cayenne.  My Cajun is already hot and the andouille can run hot as well,. 2 cans of chicken stock, we like it a little saucier. We put our rice in a bowl and added Jambo on top.  I think if I told my father-in-law I was making this again he would travel from IA to have it.  Very Good

Fantastic and so easy !  I followed the recipe except I had a heavy hand on the Cajun seasoning and red pepper.  This will be a repeat in our house for sure- and also company worthy.  Only note- when I mixed it all in crockpot it seemed thick but as it cooked the liquids released and it was soupy.  This doesn't bother us, gives the rice something to soak up.  I cooked on High for 4 hours and added the shrimp with one hour left.    Thanks for the recipe !

text:
I really loved this recipe!  I did not know what andoullie  sausage was/couldn't find it/ therefore didn't have it. I took another reviewers suggestion for this problem and used keilbosa and added more cayenne to add more spiciness.   I cooked 1 cup rice (which made 2 cups), and added it at the end. It does soak up all the liquid even if its precooked. The recipe calls for the Jambalaya to be served OVER the rice, so those complaining it soaked it up, we weren't supposed to put it in the pot. I did because I like it mixed. Next time I'll only cook 1/2 cup of rice if I'm going to mix it in.  My hubby took it to his mothers the next day (work at family business), and every ate it, and some took it for lunch the following day!  Thanks for a great recipe!

text:
I really loved this.  The only things I differently were to use Fire Roasted Tomatoes instead of stewed, used 2 Anaheim Chiles in lieu of the Bell Pepper, used about 1/2 of a large onion, used kielbasa instead of Andouille because that's what I had and left out the celery because I didn't have any.  I made some long grain rice in my rice cooker, poured the jambalaya over the rice and it was excellent.  It is more like a soup (very brothy) but does well over the rice.  You can always thicken it up w/Wondra or even cornstarch, I prefer Wondra however.

This was great! It was a bit soupy, but I cooked rice on the side and then ladled the jambalaya over it and topped with diced salad onions - delicious! I wasn't able to get andouille, so I used kielbasa instead and 'kicked the cayenne up a notch' as one reviewer suggested - but a notch is definitely a notch, not another half teaspoon! I used about 1.25 cayenne all in and it was a bit too hot - so word to the wise for those that can't get andouille. In all, a fab recipe that my boyfriend and I will be enjoying for 2 more (very satisfying) meals - thanks for posting!

I thought this had great flavor and was quite easy.  I found that the chicken and veggies were perfect cooked on high for four hours.  Not sure what all the fuss was about it being soupy!  I just followed the advice of other reviewers and stirred in 4 1/2 cups of cooked rice right at the end to absorb the liquid(1 packet of saffron rice cooked w/ 1 dry cup of white rice).  Easy for a work lunch potluck because it only needs to cook for four hours.

This was a huge hit!  I threw all the ingredients in the crockpot this morning and by the end of the football games there was a wonderful aroma throughout the house and dinner was ready.  I did not add the shrimp as my daughter does not like seafood, but otherwise I followed the recipe exactly.  My husband and I loved the spicyness, but next time I will probably use half the amount of cajun seasoning and cayan pepper because it was a little spicy for my daughter.  It was very yummy and a definate keeper!

userID:
2143079
Display Name:
humster
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
14
favoritesCount:
145
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674168.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I combined this recipe with "The Captain's Famous Jambalaya" due to limited ingredients on hand and wanting to use the slow cooker, but I liked the result soooo much I had to post about it.  Here's how I varied it and it resulted in a gumbo type dish with a thick, rich, savory brown gravy.  In saucepan 2 tbs butter, 2 tbs flour-whisk roux 3 min.  Add 1 tbs old bay, 2 chopped onions and chopped garlic, cook til tender (10min). Season w/ ground oregano, dry parsley, 1 tsp cayenne pepper, dry thyme, black pepper, celery salt, ground allspice, ground cloves(amazing mmm) -use recipes to guide amounts. Dump roux into slow cooker.  Dump in 28 oz can diced tomatoes, 2 cups chicken broth, approx 1 lb cubed chicken breast, 1/2 lb sausage.  Cooked 4 hours on high, added approx 1 lb shrimp last 30 min.  Add more celery salt to taste.  I didn't have any celery or bell pepper, but didn't miss it at all.  One ladle of hot package-made rice pilaf into a bowl and then one ladle of "gumbo" from slow cooker and I thought it was great!  
Future possible additions/substitutions for tweaking: more butter, crawfish, crab claws, red snapper, file powder, chopped celery.  I will probably not add the bell pepper because I loved it without.

text:
This receipe is not a traditional Jambalya as prepared in the Creolen/Cajun  kitchens in the great city of New Orleans. 
The flavor ican be made more authentic by adding two lafge, or three small Bay leaves. 
In my family the skin of the Andouille 
was removed.
Also, you might try fresh parsley.
Also, and important, The rice is cooked in the in the Jambalaya..

text:
This recipe is to die for! This is the only recipe my family and I use when making Jambalaya. My parents usually triple the recipe when they make it, so they can freeze it and thaw it out for dinner randomly. I don't really care for spicy foods, but this one I can handle. If you want it a little less spicy just decrease the amount of cayenne pepper. I will say I have done that before and I didn't like it as much so I just use the recommended amount and have my water close by if I need it. (: We ALWAYS serve this with Basmati rice. 10/10 recommend this recipe.

country:

text:
I LOVE this recipe. I have made it like 10+ times and it always turns out delicious. Sometimes I add a bit more cajun seasoning for a bigger kick, sometimes I leave out the shrimp if I don’t have it. Always great. I find that if you cook
the rice separately and add it in about 30 mins before serving it absorbs the juices nicely. I’ve also made it in my instant pot with rice included and it works great! I just found a random instant pot jambalaya recipe and used that cook time. It doesn’t make your whole house smell delicious like the slow cooker version but it takes less
than an hour from prep to eating! What was an all day cooking meal became a quick after work dinner. :)

Display Name:
Murr T. Haynes

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/4949212.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
It is about time someone knows the difference between Cajun and Creole cuisine.  I see so many recipes labeled "Cajun" and it is for a gumbo and they put tomatoes, okra and filet into them.  NOT CAJUN!  Cajun cuisine developed mostly from the resettled Adrienne French that were relocated primarily to the areas around Lafayette, La.   New Orleans had a diverse mix of Spanish, Creoles, German and Caucasion people from the North.  There was some crossover, but the cuisines developed their own distinct styles that remain to this day.  Your recipe definitely smacks of the Creole style as the Cajun style is made with a brown gravy instead of a tomato gravy.  I praise you for pointing out the difference.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2019-07-15T13:09:59.16
helpfulCount:
0

Delicious!  Made pretty much to the recipe, but added tomato paste, gumbo file, chopped jalapenos, extra garlic, upped the spices a tad, used 12 oz Andouille and 2 lbs of shrimp. text:
Yes, I changed the recipe.  I cut the recipe in half for just me and my husband.
I used Old Bay sausage instead of the andouille.
Instead of Cajun seasoning, I used Old Bay seasoning. 
I skipped the cayenne pepper and the shrimp.
I cooked just the seasonings, broth, and tomatoes for about 5 hours.
I then put in the onion, bell pepper, and celery (I waited so they would still be a little firm and not mushy).  I let them cook for about 15 minutes.
At that point I put 1C of minute rice.  I continued to cook for about 15 minutes.
It was DELICIOUS and the rice soaked up a lot of the liquid that others complained about.

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
I didn't add the 1 t. cayenne pepper because that would have been too hot for my Dad.  I used Sweet Italian Sausage links  cut up because that was what I had on hand.  For the chicken broth, I used 1 t. Better Than Bouillon in a cup of water. It has great flavor!  I served with rice.  It was ok, but we felt it was too thin a broth.  So for the leftovers, I added a can of tomato paste and another cup of the Better Than Bouillon Chicken broth.  I also added a package of sliced Andouille sausage.   Served this time over angle hair spaghetti.  It was a hit.  It had much more flavor and I'd fix it again this way. It was nice having the two types of sausage, chicken and shrimp all in one dish.  I might would give it 5 stars with my additions.  Add the cayenne pepper if you like the extra heat. The Cajun seasoning and andouille sausage was enough spice for us.

text:
I know I have a sensitivity to foods that are too spicy hot so I cut the Cajun spice and Cayenne measures in half. The resulting dish was still way too spicy hot. In fact, it was so hot my wife could not eat it and I quit after half a portion. So hot I couldn't taste the food. Also, the chicken got way over cooked and was dry. I'd suggest dark meat instead of breast. If I ever make this again, I won't use this recipe. I realize many people like hot stuff, but this is way too much for me.

I made this for an office lunch for everyone. There wasn't a spec left! Just enough heat to make it interesting but not unpleasant. Easy to fix. I prepared everything the night before in the crock of the slow cooker and left it to marinate overnight in the refrigerator. Then arrived a work at 8, set the slow cooker to 4 hours on high. Added the frozen shrimp 30 minutes before. It filled the whole office with a wonderful savory smell.

Display Name:
Sue S
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674139.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
After reading the other reviews I decided to stick with the recipe with two exceptions. I omitted the celery and added red and yellow peppers in its place. I also used thawed uncooked shrimp and cooked them the last 5-10 min to avoid adding more liquid from the ice crystals and to avoid rubbery shrimp. Both of these changes worked well. There was a lot of liquid as previously noted so I decided to use it to cook the rice in a separate pot and the solids from the tomatoes caused the rice to burn. I was able to rescue most of it by not scraping the pan and added more water in a new pan to allow it to finish cooking. The flavor was great for both the rice and the jambalaya but when I make it again I’ll try adding the rice to the slow cooker directly.
Review:

5

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674167.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Being a native of the Deep South and having lived in Louisiana for several years, the only thing wrong with this recipe is the name.  This is a gumbo recipe, not jambalaya.  Gumbo is more of a soup/stew served over rice.  Jambalaya is closer to a casserole with rice cooked in it.  If your are in Cajun country and want a dish similar to this, order Gumbo, not Jambalaya.
That said, this is great start to family recipe, which all of the best gumbo and jambalaya recipes are.  My main jambalaya recipe is from a family near Fort Polk, Louisiana.   :-)
Review:
Rating:
2
dateLastModified:
2019-02-16T14:46:27.75
helpfulCount:

text:
I made this pretty much as described. I added some zucchini and mushrooms since I had them already. I didn’t use a whole pound of shrimp though since I rarely eat shrimp.. I only added maybe 1/4 pound. To compensate I used about 1.5 pounds of chicken. I was unsure of the spiciness so I only used 1 tsp of the Cajun spice and about 1/2 tsp of Cayenne. It had a good flavor but was a bit soupy so I added about 2 cups of cooked brown rice to it which gave it more substance, but it still needed to be served in a bowl. My wife loved it so I’ll be making it again. She said it was perfect.

text:
Love this recipe!  I read from other reviews that it's too soupy, and when I added my shrimp I could tell that mine was turning out that way.  I made a quick roux with 1 stick (8oz) of butter and 1/2 cup flour, and added it to the crock pot right after the shrimp.  This gave it a delicious creamy texture that was perfect over rice.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
We love this recipe in our house. We make it with chicken and smoked sausage as we don't have great andouille options where we are. We skip the shrimp. For the last half hour of cooking I cook up 4 cups of white minute rice using most all the broth from the crock pot. Once the rice is cooked I return it to the crock pot for the remainder of the cook time. This removes the soupiness and it does not end up dry. This is delicious and so simple!

text:
Delicious! Five stars from the whole fam! I made a couple of substitutions that kept it from getting too soupy (a problem I’ve had before when making jambalaya): I used crushed tomatoes, rather than diced, and (boneless and skinless) chicken thighs that I tossed in whole at the start, then shredded when I added the shrimp. Added plenty of Slap Your Mama Cajun spice mix - and BAM! The best jambalaya I have ever made! Thanks!

text:
I followed the recipe  exactly. I really wanted it to be good, but it wasn't, it really really wasn't. For one, there's quite a bit of prep time, especially for a slow cooker recipe. Second, this is not a cheap recipe either--the chicken, the sausage, the shrimp, it really adds up. Which is particularly frustrating when, Third, it's basically tasteless. I was generous with the spice measurements too. Usually, when I cook in the slow cooker, I can smell dinner from the hallway outside my apartment, and this? Nothin. Add in issue four, the leftovers don't reheat well. TLDR; Too expensive ingredients, too much prep time, not enough flavor, and needs to be consumed in one sitting. Just not cutting it for me.

text:
Another slow cooker recipe for the Instant Pot. 

Used partially frozen chicken (no shrimp - food allergies),  pressed the Poultry button, sat down with a glass of chard, and about 30 minutes later, the jambalaya and rice were done! It was a little loose, so if you prefer a thicker jamba, reduce the liquids. I stirred in the rice and thought it was about right.

Delicious, quick and easy. Thanks for the recipe.

text:
This is  an outstanding recipe.  I pay about $12.00 for a bowl at a lovely seafood restaurant and this is better than theirs.  I used AmyLu's chicken Andouille sausage because I am obsessed with it.  The only tomatoes I had were diced fire-roasted with green chilies (Rotel) so I adjusted the cayenne.  Created my own Cajun seasoning since I had none (search Allrecipes for the recipe) and it is wonderful.  I doubled the recipe and am now trying to determine if I can freeze it.  Mine is a lovely  thick soupy result, with brown rice put in the last 30 minutes along with the shrimp.  I will make this many times over.  A definite favorite!  I loved making it in the slow cooker but  you can make on stovetop if you are home and can keep an eye on it.  Thank you for this recipe!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5876003.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is definitely a decent, easy to put together jambalaya. I really get annoyed with crock pot meals that you have to cook and sauté everything up before you put it all into the crock pot. Hubby said it was good but he likes some other recipes I’ve made of this better. I did use boneless skinless chicken thighs rather than breasts as we don’t like the blandness of breasts. We also don’t eat pork so I bought turkey hot Italian sausage. I know Italian is not andouille but if I can’t  find turkey andouille...I did not cut any of the meat up and I’m glad of that. I cooked it all for just 7 hours and by then the meat had all pretty much disintegrated into shreds. Which really wasn’t a bad thing, but if you like the meat to be in chunks it won’t be. Everything else was as exactly as the recipe called for. Served it over brown rice. It has a lot of flavor and I will make it again.

userID:
9183358
Display Name:
watchtime
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/933419.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Had a big 2lb. bag of shrimp and I was searching for a Cajun/Creole dish that I couldn't remember the name of and "jambalaya" came up.  Actually my son reminded me that "gumbo" was what I was looking for.  Oh well.  Anyway, I doubled this recipe following the directions exactly as far as the spices/cooking were concerned.  Didn't have andouile or celery and wasn't about to go to store.  I did have in inventory Italian sausage, asparagus, hard salami and celery seeds.   Worthy substitutes as it turned out. 

Came out awesome.  Read a couple of the other reviews and added a little instant brown rice to suck up the excess liquid in the crockpot, used Tony Chachere's spice and that worked out fine.  Boiled the shrimp "bones" and used that broth for the rice which I used Goya Arroz Amarillo yellow rice mix. 

I used RAW shrimp and "put shrimp in the last 30 minutes" is still too long.  Shrimp cooks fast and 15-20 mins at the end is plenty.

Next time I guess I'll use the andouile sausage and celery, omit the cayenne and use ground Ghost Pepper (I grow them) probably a quarter to a half teaspoon for the whole pot (if I use more nobody else will eat it.)

Bottom line?  This recipe is easy and really good.  A winner!
Review:
Rating:
5

I don't know what you'd call this, but it is NOT Jambalaya!   Jambalaya is Not meat & vegetables  served Over Rice;  Jambalaya IS  Rice with tomatoes, meats, spices, etc. cooked IN IT!  Here in the south we laugh our butts off at people who call this Jambalaya!  At Best; this is Only a Sauce!!!

text:
We have made this MANY times since I found the recipe - I think 4 years ago.  It is our go-to creole recipe.
The ONLY changes that we make is 1) we use kielbasa as andouille is sometimes difficult to find and 2) we halve all of the "hot spices" then serve hot sauce with it for those who want more heat.  We ALWAYS serve it over rice and usually with cornbread as a side.
GREAT recipe!

text:
I made this for a Mardi Gras pot luck at work last week and it was a hit!  People were going back for second's and there wasn't any left at the end of the day.  I made the dish as is, but I added a bit more chicken stock and a bit more pepper because the chicken I added was more than a pound.  It is a little bit soupy, but perfect for ladling over rice and having that rice absorb all of that great flavor. I hate mushy rice, so I found this perfect to cook it on the side. I also used salad shrimp which are much smaller, but they go a bit further.  I'm actually making a pot for myself today since we ran out at work and it was that good.  Four people asked me for the recipe that day, so I'd say this one is a winner!

Excellent!  Made nearly just as written, including the liquid with the tomatoes, for 4 hours on high, then 30 minutes.  Used Tony Chachere's Creole seasoning.   Excellent flavor, and just right!

I did add 1 3/4 cups of instant brown rice when I added the shrimp, and it was perfect consistency to serve.  I added the rest of the can of broth to the leftovers in the fridge -- it's a still bit thick reheating because of the rice, though -- I do like it a little soupy.   

Looking forward to enjoying the leftovers in these last days of Mardi Gras!  Thank you!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was a really good recipe.  I used chicken thighs instead of chicken breasts because that's what I had on hand.  I didn't think it was too spicy at all.  I cooked the rice separately and added it to the slow cooker at the end.  It was very soupy at first, even after draining the tomatoes.  However about an hour after adding the rice on the warm setting, it had soaked up a lot of liquid and began to resemble more of a traditional jambalaya.  I'll definitely make this again as it was super-easy to throw it together and smelled fantastic while cooking.

text:
This dish was absolutely delicious! I followed the other reviewers advice  and omitted the juice from the can of tomatoes to avoid a soupy consistency. I also chose to pre-cook the rice before adding it to the slow cooker at the end, before serving. Everything came out perfect. I feel like this is a recipe you can play with a little to accommodate your preference. Gave a nice kick of flavor that my entire family enjoyed!

text:
This is as good as a real Cajun Jambalaya gets. I have made it many times. Once I sized the recipe for 50 people. I used a stock pot instead of slow cooker. All of the folks I was feeding were from New Orleans. I wound up with 3 gallons and there was less than one serving left at the end of the potluck.. It scales easily, is easy to reheat for a large potluck and is about as healthy as any one pot meal you can make. It is a great fall dish. Make it 24 hours before you plan to eat it for best results.

None
country:
None
text:
I didn't feel like chopping up chicken so I added bone in thighs- before I serve it I pull out the chicken which has fallen off the bone and shred the big pieces and toss the bones. It does end up kinda soupy, so I used the broth to cook rice- there ended up being over 4 cups of broth- which was plenty for 2 cups of rice, and it made the rice taste amazing by itself!! Mixed the rice in and that soaked up more broth. This has become a family favorite as well as a go-to for game night and pot lucks!

text:
This is absolutely delicious!  We made a few changes, but I feel sure it would be equally delicious in the original recipe form.  For anyone who's interested:

We skipped the celery, halved the cayenne pepper.  I added 1/2 tsp each of garlic powder, sweet Hungarian paprika, Liquid Smoke and a 1/4 tsp each of seasoning salt and black pepper.  I cooked the diced chicken before adding it, which resulted in super tender chicken.  Finally, we used smoked summer sausage.  The subs. cut down the spice a bit, and it was perfect over basmati rice.  Great recipe!  Thanks so much for sharing!

text:
I've made this several times and each time it gets better and better. If made as written, it's a little too bland for our family so I always increase the spices during  the last two hours of cooking. By then, the Jambalaya has had time to form its true flavor so that you can adjust the spices more accurately. Also, when added on top of rice the flavor gets too dispersed. To maintain the rich flavor, I always add the cooked rice into the pot during the final 30 minutes to soak in the spices. Lastly, I'm too cheap to buy shrimp unless it's on sale, so I just add a little more chicken to compensate. Tastes great! Thank you for this wonderful recipe!

I also poured some of the juice out before company arrived and put it in the fridge for leftovers.  I am not a super-hot-food fan and this was not too hot.  The sour cream on the side was great.  Thanks for a terrific holiday meal.

text:
I really like this recipe and had made it once before.  I followed the recipe exactly the first time and it was a bit spicy for my boyfriend and our daughter, so when I made it the second time, I cut the spicy spices down in half and it was great for my daughter.  She was able to enjoy it.  I also added in the rice 2 hours and 40 minutes before we were ready to eat, because I was cooking on slow (I believe it's 2 hours prior to serving if you are cooking on high).  I accidentally over-riced it by putting two cups of rice in, because I was estimating how much liquid was in it, so it was not soupy at all.  I liked it anyway, but I would recommend only putting in one cup of rice.  I also left out the shrimp, because I'm the only one who likes the shrimp.  It was excellent.

text:
Great recipe to make for a pot luck or a sick friend since most people don't cook Cajun recipes on a regular basis (at least not in Florida). I cut the cayenne in 1/2...still has a nice "bite" at the end. Used large cooked shrimp the 2nd time I made it because the small ones aren't as flavorful---put them in 1 hour before finishing for more flavor. Used McCormick's organic spices and was very happy with the flavor. Served over Zatarain's Jambalaya rice and with corn muffins. Great Keto diet meal if you skip the rice and bread.

userID:
7164275
Display Name:
devadetta
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0

0
madeRecipesCount:
3
favoritesCount:
107
recipesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614261.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I wanted to follow the recipe faithfully, but had to make do with ingredients I had on hand. I did not have onion, celery, green peppers, or andouille sausage. Instead, I used one can of Rotel's diced tomatoes with green chiles (original), one can of tomato sauce, one whole scallion (chopped), three cloves of garlic (thinly sliced), and four Bourbon black peppercorn and bacon sausages. I browned the sausage, removed from pan. Then dredged the cubed chicken in flour, salt, and pepper. I then browned the chicken in the little bit of sausage drippings with the scallions and the garlic. I then put everything in the slow cooker as instructed, except I skipped the extra cayenne since I was afraid it'll be too spicy for my 4- and 8-year-olds. Instead, I used a combination of smoked and regular paprika (2 teaspoons altogether). I also had no thyme, so used a bay leaf. After nearly 7.5 hours on low, I skimmed the fat off the surface of the jambalaya and put in raw shrimp (frozen) with 37 min left on the clock. The jambalaya was incredibly delicious and full of amazing flavor. Husband loved it. It was still too spicy for the children, but that's the nature of jambalaya. I will make this again - it was wonderful in spite of all the changes I had to make.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this, and thought it was a bit more soupy than I'd like.  Taste is good, but, I'd recommend some tweaks to seasoning.

1. Make your own cajun seasoning.  Half the ingredients were already called out individually, so it seemed redundant if you don't buy pre-made (I couldn't even find it in my store).
2. I used frozen, pre-shelled shrimp.  I put it in about 1 hour before the 4 hour mark while cooking on high.
3. I definitely recommend not cooking the rice with the stew.  This is a traditional way to cook jambalaya, but the slow cooker will make it mushy.

text:
This is a great jambalaya recipe.  My husband and I both loved it.  The recipe as written is very spicy though.  If you love spicy it's great but if not, I'd definitely reduce the amount of cayenne pepper added.  The Andouille sausage & creole seasoning (I used Tony Chachere's and even though I used the non-spicy version, it still has a kick) already have some spiciness on their own without adding additional cayenne pepper.  I used only a 1/4 of a teaspoon cayenne pepper instead of 1 whole teaspoon like the recipes calls for and it was plenty spicy for us.  Otherwise, good, rich flavor & the consistency was great.  I served over brown rice.

text:
Made it for the first time tonight.  I don't typically stick to set limits for spices and go by taste.  It came out perfectly!  I added a little more sausage to mine, omitted the shrimp due to allergies, and cooked the rice then mixed it in with the jambalaya as I like mine thicker instead of like a soup.  I also added a bit of corn starch to the jambalaya to thicken up the sauce and give it a more hearty consistency.  Overall, it was just the right amount of heat, and just the right taste!  As a veteran of The Big Easy and its amazing food, this definitely compares to the real thing!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this recipe twice and it has become a "fan favorite" with my co-workers. I changed the recipe slightly to spice it up by cutting the diced tomatoes to one 14.5 oz can and adding a can of Rotel Hot chilies. This adds more depth to the flavor and some real heat (don't use the "hot" chilies if you don't like your food really spicy). And to "kick the recipe over the goal post" of the flavor field, I cooked raw shrimp in spicy crawfish boil before adding to the jambalaya. 

This is an unbelievably easy recipe that has tons of flavor. This recipe trumps any jambalaya I've eat at most Louisiana or Cajun restaurants in Houston, TX.

text:
Didn't have the thyme, but otherwise followed pretty close.  Added my Dirty Rice mix (boxed) with 30 minutes to go.  Will add shrimp tomorrow after I reheat for Mother's Day (I figure about 20 minutes to heat the already cooked shrimp).  

So far, this is a fantastic recipe based on my preliminary tasting.  I did use chicken thighs and de-skinned and cut into pieces.  I've made Jambalaya before, but this is the best to date.  And no, you don't need garlic.  A little soupy, but with the rice addition, it is perfection.  Enjoy!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Made it a few times with some variations.  I don't usually have andouille on hand, so tend to use a number of different smoked sausages, some spicy and some not.  I usually add some fresh garlic too, and I am pretty flexible on my vegetable quantities.  I like using shrimp that still have their shells, it adds a little bit of extra taste.  Also, I don't pay too much attention to the liquid amounts --- I have found that I can easily remove the extra liquid and use it to make the rice at the end, which gives very yummy rice to mix into the jambalaya as desired.  Overall, this recipe, whether you want to call it a true jambalaya or not, is a very tasty dish.

text:
Fantastic! 
I tried Jambalaya when I was a kid and it blew my mind. I loved the chewy shrimp and flavorful sausage. I just got a crock pot and have been wanting to put it to good use. This recipe was a fantastic base to springboard off of and has the perfect balance of seasoning. It's hard to find anything worth changing, so all I did was add an array of hot sauces to try. 

Thank you so much for sharing this with the world, and giving a solid A++ Jambalaya to the internet. 

Side notes: The whole thing cost relatively close to $10 bucks, fed 5 people and took no more than 20 minutes as stated. 
You could make this on the way out the door for work and then by the time you got home it would be ready. 

Crock potting is magical. Thanks again!

text:
Made this as written except I omitted the shrimp (hubby doesn't like them) and I reduced the spices slightly so my 4yo will eat it. It tastes pretty good,but it is very watery. I added some instant rice after I had turned the heat off and let that cook which absorbed some of the liquid, and then served with a crusty bread to mop up the rest. If you don't plan on adding rice or serving with bread, i suggest you seriously reduce the liquid added to this. Other than that it's a pretty good dish.

text:
I really liked it. Once I was visiting friends in Louisiana and the neighbor made a Jambalaya in a black pot over a fire. He killed his own chickens and used caught that day shrimp with homemade sausage. I remember it being soupy and the rice was served on the side. I don't think anything on here will be that authentic. So my one experience with "real" jambalaya was pretty close to this in soupiness and rice on the side. So I do not agree with the statement that "it should have rice in it". I made it just the way the recipie called for. I will make it again.

text:
I like having the rice included in the pot, so I added one box of Zatarain's New Orleans Style Jambalaya Mix to this recipe. The recipe called for a cup of broth, which is about 1/2 a can - the rice called for 2.5 cups of liquid - so I added the other 1/2 can of chicken broth and a 1/2 cup water. Came out perfectly. 

I also 1/2 the cayenne pepper to decrease the heat a bit. I only put it on high for 4 hours.  I tried to upload a picture but was unsuccessful :(

userID:
4860396
Display Name:
Elucidate
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3065694.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
My fourth time making it. Here are a few suggestions. Follow recipe with the followings changes and additions based mostly on other reviewers. Cube chicken, season salt/pepper then dredge in flour and sear to brown outside. 2 medium onions or 1 large+, 3 stalks celery, full can chicken broth, 1.5 level tsp cayenne pepper, 2 tbsp minced garlic, 1 can tomato paste, use seasoned diced tomatoes (eg sweet onion garlic) and most importantly, I threw in king crab meat and shells until the slow cooker couldn't fit any more. The shells will add great seafood flavor. Throw in a bag of dried shrimp. Then I use U15 shrimp and large grade A sea scallops. Cut shrimp into bite size, add shellfish to the pot with 5 minutes left of cook time (assumes shellfish are close to room temperature). The more veggies you add the more liquid base you end up with; which IMHO is a good thing.

text:
One of the best slow cooker recipe I've tried on Allrecipes. I usually just use the sausage and no other protein. Great flavors/seasoning and I add rice from one boil-in-the-bag pouches to cook with the other ingredients; makes for a nice consistency. 

Because all my sausage is precooked, I just cook the vegetables/broth on high for two hours then added sausage and cooked for one more hour. I forget at one point I add the rice, but if I figure it out, will update the review.

text:
This was AWESOME! I'd say it's closer to 8 servings than 12, but maybe that's just because my husband and I LOVED it. Since the recipe didn't specify, I used the canned tomatoes with green chilies (we love spicy) and kept the juice as the recipe states. This did leave some remaining juice in the bottom, but soak it up with some rice or drink it straight - super good! Only thing I actually changed was adding more onion 'cuz my hubby loves it and a tiny bit of garlic. Andouille sausage turned out tender and really contributed to the flavor. I've never had good experience adding rice to a slow cooker recipe, so I cooked mine on the side and added it in once it was cooked. Definitely a keeper and will make again soon!

Super easy to make. Complex in flavor. Well worth it in you're looking for that cajun taste. city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've made this a few times now.... Changed it up a little each time, of course.... It's a very versatile recipe! Like added some chopped garlic cloves; turmeric, Italian spice, & the Keg Steak spice to add more heat & flavour to it (sometimes more spice, sometimes less, depending on what else I'm cooking & who I'm cooking for)... And I've found that this particular recipe is a little watery, so I do add brown rice to it (otherwise it wouldn't be right!) I can't digest red meat, so I use turkey sausage, (I know, what a rip-off, but that was the hand I was dealt with... At least I can eat some meat!) Also, I prefer thigh meat to breast meat for the nutritional value, so that's what I usually use as well, and if I can find prawns, I will use that instead of shrimp (prawns are also better nutritionally...I used to be a commercial fisher-woman in the '90's, but they are hard to find, seasonal usually April - Sept as they have to be trapped). This is a great dish to bring to a large gathering... My family really love it when I bring it up when I visit (we each bring a dish so my 72 yrs young Mom doesn't have to cook so much & can visit with us, too, even though she loves to fuss while she visits!)

text:
This is the first time cooking jambalaya and I just had my first bite and it was delicious. I doubled everything because I meal-prep. If you follow step-by-step, you'll get a soupy jambalaya and if you ever talk to someone from Lousiana, they'll tell you that it is not supposed to. After it was cooked, I removed as much liquid as possible and I cooked two cups of white rice. I still added some water because it was taking too long. I just watched it and stirred it until it was cooked. I added the rice to the slow cooker. The liquid was delicious and I am saving the remaining.

text:
LOVED IT! I'm a huge fan of all things spicy ...my family, not so much, so I toned it down at the end with a bit of cream. Also, the broth stayed pretty thin, so I took some broth out and warmed it in a saucepan with 2 teaspoons of cornstarch-added it back in and it's PERFECT! I've experimented with complicated jambalaya and gumbo recipes for years-this is by far the simplest and best I've tried. Also, I doubled the shrimp-because SHRIMP!! Thanks so much for sharing!

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
Based on reviews, I made a very minor change....in summary the jambalaya was AWESOME!!!! The only thing I changed was the amount of cayenne pepper (b/c most reviewers said it was really hot). There was a kick but I think the recommended amount would be just fine also (as my way wasn't really spicy at all)....oh and many on here expressed concern about the "soupiness" but that wasn't an issue for me. I used the juice from the tomatoes (as the recipe calls for instead of draining) and it was just fine. I used a spoon with holes (to drain) when I made plates and then used a regular serving spoon to add just a little juice....I didn't want to do like some of the other reviewers and omit the juice from the recipe and then end of up with completely dry jambalaya. Again, it was AWESOME and will now be a staple in my house. Thanks for sharing the recipe Colleen.

text:
For those complaining about it being too runny, I added a roux thickening while it was cooking. About 2-3 tablespoons by Zataran's. Also, I didn't have any Cajun seasoning, so I used 2T loose seafood boil by Zataran's as well. Added some minced garlic and mushrooms. Also, took the cooked rice and poured it into the slow cooker ingredients right before serving. My family and friends loved it.

I also added a chicken bouillon cube.  I used all organic ingredients.  This was easy to make :)

text:
I absolutely love jambalaya, it's one of my favorites things to eat in the winter time.  The only change that I made was using brown rice instead of white, but the taste was still the same.  I've made this dish twice now, the first time without red pepper flakes and the second with, and I definitely tasted the difference.  It was a little bit hotter with the red pepper flakes, but I paired it with some cornbread and that took away the heat.  This will definitely be a slow cooker dish I make for years to come!

text:
Almost followed recipe exactly except I omitted the shrimp and substituted 1 lb beef stew meat for the chicken.Drained about 60% of the liquid from the diced tomatoes and it is a perfect consistency. Prepare the rice separately.  Make sure you don't go cheap on the sausage; go to the market and spend a little more, you will know the difference.

text:
It was fantastic! Everyone loved it! We aren't big on spice though so I substituted the cayenne and cajun for a half tsp of red pepper flakes, added a bit more chicken broth (1/8 cup) and didn't add shrimp. We ate it served on crackers, which was fantastic! I would recommend this to anyone, even someone who isn't big on spice!

text:
This was delicious. .of course I added my own touch with some help with other reviews...I only had one 14 oz can of diced tomatoes so I also used some cherry tomatos I had in the fridge I cut them in half..I added 2 tsps fresh minced garlic..no cayenne so I used 4 tablespoons tony catchers creole seasoning and sprinkled red pepper flakes...also used beef smoked sausage...and browned the sausage chicken onion pepper and celery in a pan before hand but only for a few mins..drained and added to crock pot..also I dont like thyme so I used sage....added can of tomato paste..and cooked rice in chicken broth seperatly but only half cooked the rice and added it when I added the shrimp and turnes it on high for the last hour

text:
MY FAMILY WENT NUTS OVER THIS RECIPE....THEY LOVED IT. I had to make a few altercations because most of them don't eat pork (I am strictly a seafood eater no other meats....so I didn't get any of this....made a separate seafood only batch for myself). I used turkey and beef sausage for my families pot full. It was not hard to put any of it together I did have to go out and purchase a REAL slow cooker... lol mine was only a 2qt so besides that and a lot of chopping it was a snap. I didn't have time to do the eight hours so I put it on high and did the 4 hours adding the shrimp last (as suggested) it was a hot (not for taste but as in great) hit... Thanks for the different suggestions and Colleen thanks for the recipe.

text:
I dont make alot of cajun food, but I do enjoy the spices in cajun/creole cooking. I made this recipe as instructed. It smells delicious while it was cooking. I took other reviewers suggestion to cook the rice in its original juice last 1/2 hour of cooking (so it isn't so runny). But I was just unimpressed with the flavors. I am not sure what spice overpowered the dish, but I just didn't like it. My husband ate it and felt the same way. Won't be making this again!

text:
OMG! amazing, while helping with hurricane Sandy's displaced people, our camp cooks prepared Jambalaya, it was my first time ever eating it, this recipe is so close to the flavors. I added extra hot sauce. after six hours of slow cooking transferred all ingredients, minus two cups of liquid, to my electric skillet containing white cooked rice and 1 lb. cooked and peeled shrimp. as the rice thickened the dish I added the remaining liquid as need. I would make this dish again, and again.

text:
SO GOOD, but I made some changes:

I don't eat chicken so I added an extra cup of broth to acct for the loss of chicken juices.
I doubled the amount of shrimp and sausage.
And I don't eat sausage so I used Gimme Lean vegan tofu sausage. AMAZING.

With 3 hrs to go on low, I added brown rice. After it was done officially cooking, I left it on keep warm for a few extra hours when I went to run errands. And when I came back, the rice had absorbed all of the liquid. AND IT WAS DELICIOUS.

text:
I have cooled this 3 times and it has always turned out great. The last 2 times I used chicken thighs with the bones and skin. After cooking I removed the skin and bones and used the cooking broth instead of canned chicken broth. I have also added a pound of cubed ham for a more meaty jambalaya. We always have a lot left over so we cook the rice separately each time we serve this. The left overs get spicier and taste better.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I may have already reviewed this recipe but it has become a go-to in our house so I wanted to make sure I left a review.  I am from Houston originally and therefore have had some great Jambalaya on trips to Louisiana and in restaurants in the area as Cajun cooking definitely has spread to east Texas. This is a VERY EASY recipe that is great for busy folks with kids as it is authentic in taste and takes so little time to prepare in the crockpot.  Although the rice does not cook with it, the flavor is so rich because it cooks for so long that even after you pour it on regular rice, you still get a great flavor.  I follow the recipe although I measure by sight but if you want to tone down the spiciness, just add less of the hot stuff!  I think if you add all the liquids called for and maybe some extra chicken broth you could throw instant rice in there and it would cook up fine.  I may try that myself and if it works, I will post another review.  Just hate to waste expensive shrimp and ruin the recipe.  May get brave enough one day! Thanks for the recipe!  It is a family favorite as well as all guests who have tried it.

userID:
4743586
Display Name:
Jilly

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/6092303.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was a great recipe, and SO easy to make.  I omitted the broth knowing that the veggies would put off a lot of moisture, and ended up not needing it at all.  I also cut back very slightly on the meat (all three types) because packaging is in different quantities than listed, but it still made TONS.  I subbed beef sausage for the lower fat content which turned out just fine, but I'm sure it's amazing as written... have to try it with andouille next time!
I also tossed in about a teaspoon of roasted garlic (will probably double or triple that next time) and a teaspoon of very spicy, roasted pepper pureé at the end of cooking since it's quite mild as written.  Thinking I will use Rotel instead of just diced tomatoes next time as well for the added kick.
I served this over brown rice for dinner, and it was a big hit.  Very flavorful, simple as can be with easy to find ingredients, and of course there is the always wonderful ease of the slow cooker preparation.  With a liner, it makes for quick cleanup as well.  
Jambalaya can be intimidating since you have to leave it alone so the rice won't clump or undercook, but this version is a nice alternative allowing you to poke and stir as much (or as little) as you like and instead adding rice at the end.  This recipe is going into my regular rotation... thanks for sharing it!

text:
I made this without rice for a low carb meal.  Absolutely delicious!  I didn't have the oregano or  thyme spices so I used 2 tsp of Old Bay Seasoning instead.  I also added a heaping tsp of minced garlic.  My crock pot is broke so I made this on top of the stove.  I cooked it about an hour.  It was soupy so I thickened up the liquid with cornstarch in a side dish and then added it back in.  It gave the jamabalaya a nice thick gravy.  My husband, not as much a low carber as me, used the gravy to dip some whole grain bread slices in.  We both loved it.  I have a lot of leftovers that I am thrilled about.  I will definitely make this again!

text:
A great dish.  Was the best Jambalaya I've ever had.  However, unless you want it extremely hot, don't use a teaspoon of cayenne pepper.  I used a half teaspoon and it was very spicy.  Also, I used cooked frozen shrimp but mine turned out too tough.  Next time I'll use raw shrimp and only cook it for no more then ten minutes.  This should make a great recipe even better, I think.

country:

text:
I've made this recipe 3x so far and I absolutely love the flavor! I even made it for this past year's Xmas party and got great reviews. There's only 3 slight changes I've made to the recipe:
1) Rather than using 1 cup broth, I used the entire can (main reason is I'm an amateur cook, I don't know what else to do w/ the remaining)
2) Increased chicken to 1 1/2 lbs, per request from the boyfriend (big meat eater)
3) Added 2 cups okra. This is a personal pref in my jambalaya.  

Overall, w/ the extra broth, there was plenty of 'soup' to add the rice! Thank you for sharing the recipe with an amateur cook!

text:
I don't know how authentic this is...more of a soup than true jambalaya I believe.  Even so, this is a really good stew.  I use turkey sausage.  To cut down the spice for some people, I suggest adding a dollop of sour cream to their bowl.  This cools it off for those who aren't into much spice.  Love the flavor myself!
Also, I add the rice directly to the cooker around the same time as the shrimp.  Thickens it up and tastes fine.

country:

text:
I am giving this recipe 5 stars based on my husband's excitement.  I enjoyed it as well, but it was a bit too spicy for me.  My husband absolutely loved it!!!!!  I didn't have time to make it in a slow cooker, so I sauteed the onions in a bit of oil, added the chicken to brown, and finally added the andouille sausage.  I let it cook for a few minutes before adding the other ingredients, minus the shrimp.  I added some rice during the last 20 minutes of cooking and the thawed out shrimp during the last 10 minutes.  Spicy, yet delicious, and even better the next day!

text:
I had never made Jambalaya before, but this recipe received rave reviews from my family.  Instead of using a slow cooker I made stove top in a dutch oven.  I browned the chicken and sausage, added the vegetables along with 1 3/4 cups of long grain rice, an extra cup of chicken broth and 1 1/2 cups of water.  Instead of diced tomatoes I used crushed tomatoes.  Spices are just right.  This recipe is great and so easy to make.

text:
This recipe was horrible.  It had no flavour and was extremely thin.  The sauce was like water and the chicken was way overcooked.  I only cooked it for 7 hrs on low.  I tried thickening the sauce with corn starch and putting the rice in with the sauce, but that made it worse.  It tasted like the corn starch and the rice went to mush.  I'm very disappointed that this recipe was the top rated slow cooker jambalaya.  I couldn't give it 0 stars, so I guess it gets a 1.

When making this recipe I made a couple adjustments just because that is what I had on hand! I used "Lumberjack" Smoked sausage instead of the andoullie sausage and it turned out great! Also, after reading some other reviews I noticed someone put the chicken breasts in whole and frozen! Well seeing as I didn't start this until lunch time this worked out really well for me! Like others I started to notice that it was a little thin after cooking for a good 4 hours so I decided to try to thicken up the sauce a bit by adding tomato paste blended with a spoon full of corn starch! I was a little nervous at first but it actually turned out perfectly and boosted the flavor! Overall this is an excellent dish.. and you HAVE to serve it with cornbread too!!

Great recipe, I doubled the ingredients before hand anticipating the great turnout, so I could njoy for a few days. To lessen the juices I only added 28 oz of diced tomatoe with juice. text:
YUM!  I absolutely love anything spicy and this is so awesome for cold days!  My kids won't eat it because it's too spicy, but I definitely will and hopefully my husband will.  And honestly, you don't HAVE to have rice, and it's a nice low carb, very filling and satisfying bowl of soup/stew.  But I am currently waiting for my jambalaya flavored rice to get done cooking, about 20 more minutes and i can't wait.  Funny, i'm watching the waterboy on tv while eating this.    Only thing I did different, was used red bell pepper, cause it's all I had and put lots of sliced garlic in it and some extra cajun seasoning.  and i didn't have andouille sausage, although i'm sure that would be amazing, so i used ground vegetarian "sausage" and it's really good, but i'm sure not the same.  It's all I had though.  Super easy to put together.  I will def be making this A LOT!

text:
I made this recipe last night with the following changes and was delighted with the finished product. I omitted the cayenne because the andouille sausage and Cajun seasoning I use are plenty spicy. I also added about 4-5 cloves of sliced garlic. It is soupy, but rice absorbs the juices nicely. I packed hot rice into a one cup measure and place the packed rice into the center of a large rimmed soup plate. I then ladled the jambalaya around the mound of rice and sprinkled fresh minced parsley on it as a garnish. My guests said it was "restaurant quality."

text:
Excellent! I added garlic, used 2 cans of Rotel tomatoes with chiles (plus all the juice) and ended up adding another can of garlic & onion tomatoes towards the end along with some chicken broth to create enough juice so I could add rice during the last hour as others suggested.  I cooked it on high for 3 hours before adding the rice so maybe when I make it again I will reduce the cook time a bit.  I omitted the cayenne pepper b/c I was afraid it would be too hot - it had a good kick to it but next time I'll go for broke and use all the pepper.  This got better and better and we ate if for lunch two days straight until it was all gone.  Thanks, Colleen!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
i followed the exact recipe minus the cayenne pepper as i can't handle things too spicy, and i used creole seasoning as opposed to cajun seasoning because it's what i had on hand.  flavor wise it was great! and the sausage had just enough kick for me - the cayenne would've killed me!  i cooked it 4 1/2 hours on high, adding the shrimp at 3 1/2 hours and 2 cups of rice at 4 hours.  it was too soupy for me, thus why i added the rice on recommendation from other reviewers.  the rice definitely soaked up the liquid, however i think it soaked it up too much and the rice ended up mushy.  so maybe more rice would solve that problem however i don't know that my crockpot could hold much more!  next time i'll omit either the chicken broth or the juice from the tomoatoes to make it less soupy, probably still add the rice in as i like the flavored rice but perhaps more of it, and i'll use raw shrimp as opposed to cooked because i think raw shrimp holds more flavor.  i'll have to try it again with these changes and hopefully boost up my rating...

text:
This was absolutely delicious and one of the easiest things I've ever made. I would probably add more heat the next time around, but the andouille I used wasn't particularly spicy. I also had a little bit of a challenge slicing the uncooked andouille so I actually cooked it like bulk sausage rather than sliced.   I served this with white rice and people couldn't get enough. It's also great reheated (though the shrimp will get tough if you reheat it.)

This was great! Much to my disappointment, my grocery store was out of peppers and andouille sausage (right before the Superbowl and 2 feet of snow), so I omitted the pepper and used smoked sausage instead. I also omitted the celery, just because, and used about twice the amount of chicken broth since I didn't want to store it in the fridge and have it grow mold... lol. When I put the shrimp in, I also threw in about a cup-cup and a half of brown minute rice. The rice was cooked just right in a half hour. Everyone in my house loved it, with the exception of my not normally picky 7 year old who said, "It doesn't look yummy". She did eat all the shrimp from her serving however.

text:
This was delicious.  I didn't have any andouille sausage on hand so I used smoked kielbasa.  Also I used raw shrimp which was peeled and deveined.  I followed the rest of the recipe exactly as written until the very end when I made a littled bit of roux to stir in and thicken the broth just slightly.  I cooked this on high for about 4 hours and then added the roux and the raw shrimp.  I let it cook 1 hour more.  The shrimp were cooked perfectly.  Since I don't eat a lot of rice, but my family does, I served this over the rice so that each person could choose their own amount of rice.    Very good and I'll make it again and again.

text:
UPDATE: SERVED (FROZEN,THEN THAWED) LEFTOVERS THIS PAST WK. MORAL OF THE STORY... YOU CANNOT FREEZE RICE = NOT SO GOOD. EAT THIS FRESH!!! Pretty good! My fiance & I stayed home 2day to get a few "house chores" (boring!) done. B/c it's Sun., I wanted to serve a "homey" meal (Sun. are reserved for "comfort foods" at our house). Since we were both busy, I needed something that could slow cook all day. This fit the bill perfectly! Although I liked this (my fiance was on the fence...), I think an oven-baked version would suit me better. I've been eyeing Oven Baked Jambalaya (JOSLYN) for some time now, but for convenience sake, I tried Colleen's version instead. I think I will give JOSLYN's recipe a try to next time.... My prob. w/ this is that it's a tad dry for my liking. As many others did, I too add. (3.5 c.) instant rice w/ my shrimp (which by accident, I partially thawed b4 realizing I didn't need to!) at the 3.5 hr. mark & then cooked for another 30 min. as direct. I ended up add. the rest of my can of chx. broth & this helped somewhat, but I think it was the rice that dried everything out. Having said that, it was nice to not dirty another pot (and that IS the purpose of slow cooking, right???). My only other ch. was to purchase a rotisserie chx. b/c I forgot  to thaw what I had in the freezer. Oh, and I had no prob. at all finding andouille sausage. My local Italian market had Johnsonville brand this wk. Served w/ garlic bread, this was a hearty meal! Thx. for sharing! :-)

text:
I followed this recipe fairly closely.  I sautéed the onion/pepper/celery/chicken before putting it in the crock pot and reduced the chicken broth to 1/2 cup.  I loved the result - the chicken was tender and it was nicely spiced (perhaps a tiny bit salty).  Upon cooling, the mixture thickened and so in retrospect, it probably wasn't necessary to reduce the amount of chicken broth.  I'll definitely be making this again!

text:
Wonderful!!!! I never thought such good, authentic jambalaya could be so easy! The main thing I did different was omited the shrimp (so I added a little extra chicken). I also cooked some brown rice the night before when I was preparing everything (I left it in the crockpot in the fridge over night) and stirred the rice in with 10 min to go. I used a green, red and yellow pepper pre-diced mix and used hot sauce instead of chili pepper. This is one of my favorite meals I've ever cooked!!! Thanks so much for sharing!

This recipe was fantastic.  We used a whole rotisserie chicken and used Rotel rather than regular diced tomatoes, which kicked up the spice a bit.  Added mushrooms because we had them in the house.  The only recommendation I have is to put the shrimp in an hour before completion, as they didn't quite abosorb the flavors.  The leftovers did the trick though- YUM!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677173.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Very tasty, but as other reviewers have said, very watery.  I only used 1/2 c broth, but I think next time I would leave that out, and only add it if it looked dry towards the end of the cooking time (like when adding the shrimp).  The flavor also seemed a little "flat" - next time I will use 3 tsp Cajun seasoning to see if that resolves the issue (it was plenty spicy, just missed a little "oomph").  I used boneless thighs, as it seems to me that they tend to do better with the longer cooking times required when using the slow cooker; I added uncooked shrimp at 7 hours and turned the heat to warm, and even then, the chicken was a little overdone to my taste (something to do with the texture), so next time will add the shrimp and turn to low at 6 1/2 hours.  I used Creole Seasoning (from this site), served the jambalaya over rice, and served Homestead Cornbread (also from this site) alongside, with fresh fruit as the salad.  Very nice on a rainy, blustery evening.

Although this recipe was brothy, when I added the rice (2bags of boil in bag taken out of the bags) and shrimp in the last hour (cooking on low) it thickened up beautifully and my bf loved it, the heat was doable and the sour cream topping mellowed it out great for those that couldnt handle the kick.  I cooked it 2hrs on high then 4 hrs on low so the flavors had a chance to develop. Also I added the shrimp frozen at the end so they ended up not overcooking in the hour on low heat.

text:
This recipe was awesome!  Very easy to make and tasted very very good. As for the reviews of being too watery, some jambalaya's are a little soupy for a slow cooker you just can't go wrong.  I used the creole seasoning recipe from this web site (3 Tbsp) you might just use 2 Tbsp. of the seasoning if spicy is not your thing.  Next time I will definitely use shrimp, all I had was chicken and some hillshire turkey kielbasa.  I used some left over rotisserie chicken and it was perfect, also added 1 boneless breast I recommend if you add chicken breast not to put it in until the last hour because it was a little over cooked.  But I personally will use a rotisserie chicken again next time the meat was perfect!

I love this recipe, except that I like my rice to cook with everything else.  So, I sauteed the meat and veggies, threw everything plus 1 tablespoon of sugar, minus meat, in a pot.  I included 1 part rice, 2 parts chicken stock, and cooked the rice.  The meat was added at the end to avoid overcooking.  The crockpot may reduce the pre-cooking, but my approach avoided the long cook time.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/7059540.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
My husband declared this the best jambalaya he's ever had before we even plated it. He was taking bites out of the crock pot. =)   I followed the recipe with the exception of using the Creole Seasoning that another reviewer suggested and I'm glad I did! That seasoning is delicious!! I also drained half of the tomato juice out because some people said it was soupy. Mine still came out soupy but we actually kind of liked the consistency. The juice really went well with the rice. While it was a little soupier than restaurant jambalaya the flavor was fantastic! And really, if it's too soupy for your liking just don't scoop out the juice. Thanks! (This was even better the second day! I made brown rice using 50% broth and 50% of the juice from the jambalaya and it was delicious!)

text:
this was very good.i halved it and added 1 c instant rice during the last half hr of cooking. it helped absorb some of the liquid but not all of it. i then took some of the juices from the cooker and made a cornstarch paste and cooked another 15 mins or so. this helped thicken it to the perfect consistency and almost acted loke a roux. i served it with the honey cornbread form this site.

This recipe was delicious! I did make a few changes. I used green, red, and yellow bell pepper. text:
This is remarkably fresh and flavorful coming out of the slow cooker with such little prep. I was really impressed with it, and look forward to it becoming a staple in my house. I followed the given seasoning amounts closely and thought it had a great mild-moderate, "middle of the road" kind of heat - depending on my mood and guests I may up the cajun seasonings and/or cayenne. I also found the meat/sausage/seafood amounts to be good, a little in each bite - often I increase protein in a recipe but it won't be needed in here. Thanks very much for sharing.

text:
This turned out so yummy with just a little bit of kick.  I added some blackbeans I had left over from a previous dinner and used chili pepper powder because thats all I had, also added a tsp of minced garlic.  And I just left the chicken whole to cook until right before adding the shrimp and it was very easy to shred apart in pot. This filled my 5 qt pot to the top but it cooked down.  I added 2 c. cooked brown rice at the end to reduce a little of the soupiness of it. I will still be having lots of left overs even after all my husband ate last night. I will be making this again!

text:
This was really good but I had some problems with cooking time.  I cooked it on high for 4 hours and the veggies were not done, still very very crunchy.  So, I left it alone for another hour and it still wasn't done.  I then transferred it to a pot on the stove and cooked it another 40 mins.  I had some leftover brown rice from the other day, so I added the cooked rice and the shrimp (partially defrosted) to the pot and cooked for another 5 minutes.  The rice helped somewhat with the runniness of the jambalaya, it is runny.  I used smoked turkey sausage instead of andouille because that's all I had.  It was very good and I think the next time, I will cook it all day on low instead of the high method, which didn't work out for me.

region:
