country:
None
text:
I was looking for a crockpot recipe to make on a rainy New England weekend and chose this one. I was not disappointed. The flavorful aroma assured me it would be delicious...and it was! I followed the recipe carefully making a few adjustments based on previous comments(thank you). I used boneless chicken thighs and 3 cloves of chopped garlic for more flavor. I drained the can of tomatoes before adding, using only the chicken broth for liquid, figuring I'd add the tomato juice if necessary. It was not. After 3 hours on high it was perfectly done and enjoyed over a scoopful of brown rice. The andouille sausage and seasonings give it just the right amount of heat. Hubby had 2 servings and I had 1 which left a generous serving each for lunch today. Only this morning did I realize I had forgotten the shrimp which are still in the freezer. Can't wait to try again, next time with the shrimp!

To cut the soupiness, I kept adding teaspoons of corn starch until it was the thickness I wanted.  Also, I used my boyfriend's own version of cajun spice, which was way too spicy for me.  I cut the spiciness by adding 2 tsp of rosemary and an 8oz can of tomato sauce.  Great recipe and very easy to make!!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614250.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe was so good and so easy!  I made it pretty much as written.  I added the rice along with the shrimp in the last 30 minutes of cooking.  I added 3 1/2 cups of rice and it was perfect, still juicy but not too juicy.  I will definitely leave out the shrimp next time.  It came out rubbery tasting and was even worse when re-heated.  I will up the chicken and sausage to 1 1/2 pounds a piece.  I will also put 1/2 a teaspoon instead of the full teaspoon of cayenne pepper since my husband found it to be a bit too spicy, which didn't stop him from taking seconds!  I was fine with it as it was but it did have a nice kick.  I also subbed the andouille sausage for nitrate-free unprocessed sweet italian chicken sausage just so that it would be more weight watcher friendly.  I will be making this one again for sure!

text:
I was pleasantly supprised how good this turned out. I made this minus a few ingredients so my picky family would have a better chance of liking it. I made it minus the celery, green pepper, shrimp and cayanne pepper and it still turned out very flavorful but not spicy. I added the chicken breast frozen and pulled them out about 30 min before it was done and shredded them up. I also added some rice about 30min before it was done and the rice absorbed all the flavorful juice. The only problem was after I turned off the crock pot when it was perfect the rice kept cooking because of the residual heat. Next time I think I will turn it off just before the rice is done. I will definatly make this again!

text:
Yum!  This one is going into the regular rotation ... finicky husband had THIRDS and then packed up leftovers for lunch today.  As others noted, it definitely was "soupy" even after I drained the tomatoes and decreased the amount of chicken broth. I added several cups of cooked basmati rice (basmati was all we had on hand, but worked fine) to absorb the extra liquid ... the consistency and flavor came out just right.

Initially I went light on the cayenne pepper and cajun seasoning after reading complaints that it was too spicy, but I ended up adding more at the end and the added kick was great.

I made this the other night for Mardi Gras.  I followed the recipe exactly - I might have been a little heavy on the spices as I do 'heavy teaspoons' - and it was AWESOME.  The only thing I did differently was add some frozen okra (I had to open two bags of frozen veggie mix and take out the okra - but now i have veggies for a soup so no waste) I loved it, my sister-in-law who is pregnant said it was awesome and loved the spice, and my husband loved it.  The next night - with the left-overs I just added a small can of diced tomatoes (my hubby had drained the juice the night before??) and added an extra sausage and a few more shrimp.  The first night I had corn bread which rocked.  Last night I asked my husband to pick up a crusty bread and he brought home Potato Rosemary - and it wasn't a good match at all.  But the jambalaya was awesome and the recipe is perfect as is.  I liked the extra sauce for dipping and soaking up corn bread and rice.  I wouldn't even consider giving this to my two little boys because it was making me sweat.  :)

This is very good. I would definitely try this again.

text:
I made a couple modifications to this great recipe.  First, I used 3T of the Creole Seasoning Blend on this website instead of the spices here.  I also used cajun style sausage and added 1/2 c. rice and uncooked shrimp 30 minutes before it was done as others suggested.  I also only used 1 14.5oz can of diced tomatoes since I didnt read the recipe carefully, which ended up being fine.  In the end, right before serving, I added another 2 c. of cooked rice to the mixture to soak up some of the excess broth.  This was a great recipe though next time I would cut back on the cayenne pepper!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/104860.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
We thought it was pretty good, but I messed up at the end.  After reading all the reviews about it being soupy, I added about 3/4 cup of uncooked rice along with my frozen, uncooked shrimp an hour before it was to be done.  The shrimp came out fine and the rice was good then, but we didn't eat it right away and the rice got mushy.  I think next time I'll skip the rice and just serve it over fresh-cooked rice.  Also, I used one can of diced tomoates and one can of diced tomatoes with green chilies.  I think I'll also cut back on the liquid by draining one can next time.

As for it being spicy or not, I didn't realize I was out of cayanne pepper, so mine was very mild -- which was fine for my 17m daughter and me, hubby just added Tapatio to his servings.  I think I'll make it again tho!

text:
I'm not sure how good this would have been had I not made such a huge mistake at the end. I wanted rice IN the dish as opposed to served over it. After the slow cooker was done, I made about 4 cups of rice, when the rice was fully cooked but still steaming... I added it to the slow cooker that was off at this point. I'm a nut. What a mistake.  Rice sucked up all the sauce/juice and the dish was dry. Husband loved it, but he'll eat anything. So here's you warning... don't add hot cooked rice. Flavor was still good... don't skimp on the seasonings.

This was really easy. I ended up making it on the stove. I took the advice of a few others and added a 1 1/2 cups rice to the mixes for the last portion to save on cleanup and be a little more traditional. I added some Creole seasoning and more parsley. I didn't use as much cayenne since my audience are a little "heat" sensative. But it was excellent and I will definatley make it again. Thanks so much for sharing!
Review:
Rating:
3
dateLastModified:
2006-03-12T17:22:47.17

text:
Although this was ok, it just wasn't 'rock my socks' good.  I had to do lots of doctoring...added some tomato paste to thicken it, lots more spices - cajun, creole, chipolte tabasco, garlic, onion, extra cayenne- it still didn't have the intense flavor that I associate with good jambalaya.  I cooked the rice in the crock pot like other reviewers and added extra spices to compensate, but it was still bland for me.

userID:
1403110
Display Name:
PONGGOD
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
9
favoritesCount:
47
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/global/features/72.gif
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I was looking for new ideas for using the slow cooker and this one sounded intriguing so I gave it a try. Overall, I was very satisfied with the result, although I did make some minor tweaks. Since I'm not a fan of shrimp, I ended up using about two pounds of chicken (boneless thighs). I withheld the teaspoon of cayenne since I was concerned about it being too spicy for my two kids (I felt level of spiciness was still satisfactory). I also added one bay leaf.

A number of reviewers remarked that it was too "soupy". I would agree, but this is easily correctable. Draining the excess juice from the can of diced tomatoes would be a start (I forgot to do this with mine). Also, and more importantly, adding in some cooked rice shortly before serving will help absorb most of the liquid. Rice mixed into the dish is also more typical of the jambalaya I'm familiar with as opposed to pouring the stock over it at serving time. I found that 4-5 cups worth (after cooking) seems to be about the proper ratio. My biggest mistake was leaving the rice in far too long (over an hour) which turned it into mush. 15 minutes should be plenty. This is a very tasty and easy to make dish and I'm confident my next batch will be even better.
Review:
Rating:
4
dateLastModified:
2005-05-12T05:56:07.107
helpfulCount:
0

text:
This was fabulous!  I am always looking for recipes where I can use frozen meat instead of having to remember to thaw things out. :)  The only changes I made were to omit the shrimp (I didn't have any handy), and I put about 4-5 frozen, boneless, skinless chicken thighs on the top of the rest of the ingredients.  I also took the lid off for about an hour to let things thicken up a bit.  All my family could say was YUMMM!!

This was really good. The prep work (all that chopping!) took a bit of time, but it was simple after that. I used both spicy and mild italian sausage and both were really good. Will definitely make again.
